article.heading: 5 ways to manage your workload
article.content:
Being busy at work is often a blessing. The hours fly by, and your tiredness at the end of the day comes from the satisfaction of having achieved a lot. But if your workload is too high, and the stress is becoming overwhelming, it's time to act.

There may be little you can do about your overall workload, but you can plan and manage your day so you get more done and feel less stressed.

Be early

Give yourself ten minutes before starting work to get organised. Check your diary, catch up with what has been happening and feel ready to tackle whatever the day throws at you. It's a good investment of your time.

Apply the 80/20 rule

About 80% of your day will go smoothly, but 20% will always be problematic. That's just life and it's important to remember that it's not your fault. What's worse, that last 20% may well take up 80% of your time. Use the 80/20 rule to your advantage. Identify the most urgent 20% of your tasks so that if a crisis occurs you know which things must get done.

Do the difficult things first

It's tempting to put off tough tasks. But your day will go so much better if you get the difficult things out of the way first. Having time to do them properly means you'll be less stressed. And once you're done, your to-do list will be much less scary.

Take a break

It might seem counterintuitive, but sometimes stepping back for a moment, taking a deep breath, and giving yourself time to think can help. You'll get a fresh perspective and maybe find a solution you hadn't considered before.

Add times to your to-do list

Even if they're just estimates. Once you know how long things take, you can make a more realistic plan for the day.

article.heading: Recognising stress
article.content:
We all experience stress from time to time, and that's not a bad thing. Stress is the body's response to difficult things, and it can be a positive force as well as a negative one. Feeling nervous excitement about a big event, acting quickly in an emergency or powering through a tough workout are all examples of positive stress. Psychologists call this eustress, and it can make life more interesting and fulfilling.

The opposite of eustress is distress, and as the word suggests, this type of stress can be damaging to your mental and physical health. Whether it's being driven by work or money worries, relationship problems or health concerns, stress that goes on for a long time can make you feel overwhelmed or unable to cope.

Everyone feels stress differently, so there are many different signs that you might be feeling stressed.

Stress might make you feel:

  • emotional
  • irritable
  • anxious
  • tearful

You might experience:

  • shallow breathing or hyperventilating
  • upset stomach
  • tense muscles
  • insomnia
  • jaw clenching
  • chest pains

The results of is that you might find it hard to concentrate or make decisions. You might lose interest in food or start eating too much. If you smoke or drink alcohol, you might be doing that more than usual. It's not hard to see how stress can have an impact on your physical, as well as your mental wellbeing.

It's almost impossible to illuminate stress from your life, and you might find that life would be very boring if you did. But there are things you can do to help you manage stress, and to cope with it when things get tough.
article.CTA: Are you feeling stressed? Take a quiz to find out.

article.heading: Benefits in kind
article.content:
Have you been kind to someone today? Offered help, said thank you or smiled at a stranger?

It might not seem like much, but these small acts of kindness can have a hugely positive impact. And best of all, it's a two-way thing. Compassion and kindness have been shown to reduce stress and reduce feelings of anger and anxiety in the person you're being kind to. It can even boost their immune system!

At the same time, you're also helping yourself. Kindness releases chemicals in your brain that boost your mood, promote a feeling of calmness, and even lower your blood pressure.

One of the wonderful things about kindness, is that one act of kindness tends to lead to others. If you thank someone, or acknowledge a colleague's good work, both you and they will feel good. And that feeling of social good creates a ripple effect, encouraging you both to go on and do more acts of kindness.

Like any new habit, kindness takes a bit of practice. It might feel awkward to start with, especially if you don't usually go out of your way to help others. But give it a go. Look for opportunities to demonstrate your kindness. The sense of wellbeing it gives you will soon overcome your reluctance.

article.heading: Take a microbreak
article.content:
Got 30 seconds to spare? Let's be honest, most of us do. Even the very busiest people can find 30 seconds in their frantic days. And 30 seconds is just long enough to take a microbreak, a teeny tiny break in your day that can have a surprisingly big effect.

Short breaks, or microbreaks, during the working day improve your energy, concentration and motivation. People who take microbreaks have fewer headaches, less eye strain and lower rates of back pain. Microbreaks can actually improve performance too, as they reboot your brain. If you want to get fancy about it, it's called â€˜psychological detachment'.

There's lots of science around microbreaks. For example, a study of surgeons using microbreaks during surgical procedures found that 34% reported an improvement in their mental focus and more than half reported an improvement in their physical performance. And another study, this time of computer programmers, found that microbreaks reduce muscle fatigue by as much as 50% in an 8-hour day.

What defines a microbreak is somewhat open to interpretation. Whether you should go for 20 seconds or 5 minutes doesn't seem to matter. The important thing is to schedule the breaks and stick to them. Using notifications in your calendar or an alarm on your phone can help with this.

What you do in your microbreak is also up to you, but make sure it's something that fits into the time you have and changes your focus. Here are some quick and easy microbreak ideas:

  • Stand up and stretch, either every hour or between tasks.
  • Keep a bottle of water on your workstation and sip from it often. You get an instant microbreak and will need more trips to the bathroom which gives you a slightly longer microbreak.
  • Step to the window or outside if you can for a minute or so.

article.heading: What is mindfulness?
article.content:
In simple terms, mindfulness is learning to be aware of, and focus on what's taking place in the present. It involves simple breathing exercises and other techniques that help your mind and body relax and help reduce stress. For example, you can brush your teeth in a mindful way, concentrating on the feeling of your toothbrush on your teeth and the scrubbing sound it makes; you can think of the taste of the toothpaste, and how the bubbles collect around your lips. The point is to exclude everything else and just focus on what you're experiencing in that moment.

If this all sounds a bit weird, or if you've already thought about mindfulness and decided that it's not for you, think again. Here are our 3 reasons why mindfulness might be just what you are looking for:

It's for everyone

Many millions of people from doctors and managers to top athletes use mindfulness to feel healthier and happier.

It doesn't take much time

Just yawning and stretching in a mindful way for 10 seconds each hour can make a difference. Honestly, a scientific study proved it!

It's easy to start

Like anything, you will get better the more you do. After a few goes you will easily be able to incorporate it into your daily activities.

Here's the science bit:

Scientists and psychologist have carried out lots of studies into mindfulness. They have shown that people who practice mindfulness tend to be more:

  • Satisfied with life
  • Optimistic
  • Able to let go of negative thoughts

And they tend to be less:

  • Depressed
  • Absent minded
  • Anxious in social situations

Tempted to give it a try?

Try this task which will take you through a simple mindfulness exercise.
